title: The Basel Problem: A Fourier Series Proof
text:
One of the most elegant results in analysis is the evaluation of the infinite series:
\[\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{n^2} = \frac{\pi^2}{6}\]
This problem stumped mathematicians for decades until Euler solved it in 1734. While Euler‚Äôs original proof was ingenious but not entirely rigorous, the Fourier series approach provides a clean, modern proof.

title: The Basel Problem: A Fourier Series Proof
text:
One of the most elegant results in analysis is the evaluation of the infinite series:
\[\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{n^2} = \frac{\pi^2}{6}\]
This problem stumped mathematicians for decades until Euler solved it in 1734. While Euler‚Äôs original proof was ingenious but not entirely rigorous, the Fourier series approach provides a clean, modern proof.

title: The Basel Problem: A Fourier Series Proof
text:
The Setup
Consider the function \(f(x) = x\) on the interval \([-\pi, \pi]\), extended periodically. The Fourier series for this function is:
\[f(x) = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} b_n \sin(nx)\]
where the coefficients are given by:
\[b_n = \frac{2}{\pi} \int_0^{\pi} x \sin(nx) \, dx\]

title: The Basel Problem: A Fourier Series Proof
text:
Computing the Coefficients
Let‚Äôs evaluate this integral using integration by parts:
\[\begin{align}
b_n &= \frac{2}{\pi} \int_0^{\pi} x \sin(nx) \, dx \\
&= \frac{2}{\pi} \left[ -\frac{x \cos(nx)}{n} \bigg|_0^{\pi} + \frac{1}{n} \int_0^{\pi} \cos(nx) \, dx \right] \\
&= \frac{2}{\pi} \left[ -\frac{\pi \cos(n\pi)}{n} + \frac{\sin(nx)}{n^2} \bigg|_0^{\pi} \right]
\end{align}\]
Since \(\cos(n\pi) = (-1)^n\) and \(\sin(n\pi) = 0\), we get:
\[b_n = \frac{2}{\pi} \cdot \frac{-\pi(-1)^n}{n} = \frac{-2(-1)^n}{n} = \frac{2(-1)^{n+1}}{n}\]
So our Fourier series is:
\[x = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{2(-1)^{n+1}}{n} \sin(nx), \quad x \in (-\pi, \pi)\]

title: The Basel Problem: A Fourier Series Proof
text:
Parseval‚Äôs Identity
Here‚Äôs where the magic happens. Parseval‚Äôs identity tells us that for a function \(f\) with Fourier series:
\[\frac{1}{\pi} \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} |f(x)|^2 \, dx = \frac{a_0^2}{2} + \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} (a_n^2 + b_n^2)\]
For our function \(f(x) = x\), we have only sine terms, so \(a_n = 0\) for all \(n\). Thus:
\[\frac{1}{\pi} \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} x^2 \, dx = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} b_n^2\]

title: The Basel Problem: A Fourier Series Proof
text:
The Calculation
The left side is straightforward:
\[\frac{1}{\pi} \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} x^2 \, dx = \frac{1}{\pi} \cdot \frac{2x^3}{3} \bigg|_0^{\pi} = \frac{1}{\pi} \cdot \frac{2\pi^3}{3} = \frac{2\pi^2}{3}\]
The right side gives us:
\[\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} b_n^2 = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \left(\frac{2(-1)^{n+1}}{n}\right)^2 = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{4}{n^2} = 4 \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{n^2}\]

title: The Basel Problem: A Fourier Series Proof
text:
The Final Step
Equating both sides:
\[\frac{2\pi^2}{3} = 4 \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{n^2}\]
Therefore:
\[\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{n^2} = \frac{2\pi^2}{12} = \frac{\pi^2}{6}\]
And we‚Äôre done! The Basel problem falls elegantly from the machinery of Fourier analysis. üêü

title: The Basel Problem: A Fourier Series Proof
text:
Why This Matters
This proof showcases the power of Fourier series not just for solving differential equations or signal processing, but for evaluating seemingly unrelated infinite series. The connection between the geometry of periodic functions and number-theoretic sums remains one of the most beautiful bridges in mathematics.
